```xml
	<connection>scm:git:git://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security</connection>
	<developerConnection>scm:git:git://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security</developerConnection>
	<url>https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security</url>
</scm>
```

**Expected behavior**
Expected SCM to point this repository
Expected URL to point to this repository

'https://api.github.com/users/lsteffen1/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/lsteffen1/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'labels': [{'id': 1974969182, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWwxOTc0OTY5MTgy', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/labels/type:%20enhancement', 'name': 'type: enhancement', 'color': 'e3d9fc', 'default': False, 'description': 'A general enhancement'}], 'state': 'closed', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-04-01T14:57:51Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-19T18:31:03Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-19T18:31:03Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Expected Behavior**
The path of the OpenID Connect Discovery endpoint can be configured. (e.g. in ProviderSettings like done for jwkSetEndpoint)

**Current Behavior**
The path is hard-coded to /.well-known/openid-configuration

**Context**
We want to provide the endpoints of the spring-authorization-server library within a servlet which listens to a specific path. The old deprecated spring library currently runs with another path. Both of this versions need a separate path for the Discovery endpoint. This means for us the Discovery Endpoints should be available in e.g. /oidc/v2/.well-known/openid-configuration.
Right now this path seams to be hard-coded and cannot be replaced. (OidcProviderConfigurationEndpointFilter, OidcConfigurer)

'2022-04-01T14:57:51Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-19T18:31:03Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-19T18:31:03Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Expected Behavior**
The path of the OpenID Connect Discovery endpoint can be configured. (e.g. in ProviderSettings like done for jwkSetEndpoint)

**Current Behavior**
The path is hard-coded to /.well-known/openid-configuration

**Context**
We want to provide the endpoints of the spring-authorization-server library within a servlet which listens to a specific path. The old deprecated spring library currently runs with another path. Both of this versions need a separate path for the Discovery endpoint. This means for us the Discovery Endpoints should be available in e.g. /oidc/v2/.well-known/openid-configuration.
Right now this path seams to be hard-coded and cannot be replaced. (OidcProviderConfigurationEndpointFilter, OidcConfigurer)

'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': "java.net.URL performs DNS lookups whenever its equals/hashCode is
used. Thus attribute values of type java.net.URL need to be converted
to something else before they are used for equals/hashCode.

This PR performs the conversion in equals/hashCode. Thus the
actual attributes remain the same as originally given in the
constructor. This brings some overhead from constructing a new
map in every equals/hashCode invocation, but since there likely
aren't that many attributes, I think performance doesn't need to
be considered here.

Closes gh-10673

'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jyrimatti/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': "java.net.URL performs DNS lookups whenever its equals/hashCode is
used. Thus attribute values of type java.net.URL need to be converted
to something else before they are used for equals/hashCode.

This PR performs the conversion in equals/hashCode. Thus the
actual attributes remain the same as originally given in the
constructor. This brings some overhead from constructing a new
map in every equals/hashCode invocation, but since there likely
aren't that many attributes, I think performance doesn't need to
be considered here.

Closes gh-10673

'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520.patch', 'merged_at': None}, 'body': 'Add JWT client authentication support for `private_key_jwt` and `client_secret_jwt`.

### Related specifications

**RFC 7521**
[4.2.  Using Assertions for Client Authentication](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7521#section-4.2)

**RFC 7523**
[2.2.  Using JWTs for Client Authentication](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7523#section-2.2)

**OpenID Connect Core 1.0**
[9.  Client Authentication](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#ClientAuthentication)

The best place to start to see how to configure and customize JWT client authentication support are the following tests:

- `DefaultAuthorizationCodeTokenResponseClientTests`:
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationPrivateKeyJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationClientSecretJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`

- `DefaultClientCredentialsTokenResponseClientTests`:
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationPrivateKeyJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationClientSecretJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`

Closes gh-8175', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/9520/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, http://auth-server/.well-known/openid-configuration

'created_at': '2022-03-07T21:21:59Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-15T08:24:33Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Expected Behavior**
It would be great if we could add a custom claim validator for client authentication using JWT assertion. This will allow additional validations to be done on the jwt assertion authentication.

**Current Behavior**
Right now for client authentication using JWT Assertion, DelegatingOAuth2TokenValidator comes with the default validators:  return new DelegatingOAuth2TokenValidator<>(
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.ISS, clientId::equals),
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.SUB, clientId::equals),
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.AUD, containsProviderAudience()),
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.EXP, Objects::nonNull),
                    new JwtTimestampValidator()

**Context**
In this implementation, the clients will send JWT assertions with custom claims which I am planning to validate before issuing the access token. I haven't found away to configure this.

'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520.patch', 'merged_at': None}, 'body': 'Add JWT client authentication support for `private_key_jwt` and `client_secret_jwt`.

### Related specifications

**RFC 7521**
[4.2.  Using Assertions for Client Authentication](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7521#section-4.2)

**RFC 7523**
[2.2.  Using JWTs for Client Authentication](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7523#section-2.2)

**OpenID Connect Core 1.0**
[9.  Client Authentication](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#ClientAuthentication)

The best place to start to see how to configure and customize JWT client authentication support are the following tests:

- `DefaultAuthorizationCodeTokenResponseClientTests`:
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationPrivateKeyJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationClientSecretJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`

- `DefaultClientCredentialsTokenResponseClientTests`:
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationPrivateKeyJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationClientSecretJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`

Closes gh-8175', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/9520/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'comments': 12, 'created_at': '2022-03-31T21:38:32Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-04T22:23:25Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-04T20:16:43Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory by default defines jwsAlgorithmResolver with RS256 as signature algorithm for Signed JWTs (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L86)

It provides a setter method to override and supply your own algorithm resolver (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L221). 

However, the way jwtAlgorithmResolver is being used to create NimbusJwtDecoder in  buildDecoder() function (here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L140) , it enforces only one algorithm to be supplied to NimbusJwtDecoder which it uses internally during the key selection process. 

This implementation works fine if IDP uses only one algorithm at a time as in that case, we can customize the algorithm to be used by supplying your custom jwtAlgorithmResolver using setJwsAlgorithmResolver() setter method. 

However, if IDP uses more than one algorithms to sign ID Token, there is no way we can supply all the algorithms used by IDP and so the token processing fails during the whole OIDC based authentication process when a token is signed with a different algorithm than what's used to initialize NimbusJwtDecoder through OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory. 

**To Reproduce**
Have IDP use more than one algorithm (say RS256 and ES256 both) to sign JWT and make sure it randomly alternates between these algorithms for oidc based authentication request flow. 

**Expected behavior**
As long as user has authenticated successfully, the client app should be able to process and validate IDTokens regardless of which algorithm was used out of the set of configured algorithms. 

**Sample**

Unfortunately, I can't share any code as it's private to the organization I work for, however, I'll update this ticket if I can somehow create a sample with some public IDP (e.g. google) where I can configure multiple algorithms.

> how do I pull the `id_token_signed_response_alg` from ClientRegistration metadata?

[OpenID Connect Dynamic Client Registration 1.0](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-registration-1_0.html#ClientMetadata) has not been implemented and therefore `id_token_signed_response_alg` is not available in `ClientRegistration`.

Although it's not implemented, it would not help, because:

> IDP is alternating between RS256 and ES256 per request from same client

The in-house provider implementation has implemented off-spec so this issue should be resolved with the provider instead.

The ID Token signing algorithm for a specific client **should be known at configuration time** so a `jwsAlgorithmResolver` can be configured correctly. But because the provider alternates the signing algorithm per request per client, you will need to somehow implement the custom logic in the `jwsAlgorithmResolver` to meet your requirements or log an issue with the provider to update to comply per spec.

I'll close this issue since this is directly related to the provider implementation.

", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1087972847/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'comments': 10, 'created_at': '2022-03-31T21:38:32Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-04T20:16:43Z', 'closed_at': '2022-04-04T20:16:43Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory by default defines jwsAlgorithmResolver with RS256 as signature algorithm for Signed JWTs (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L86)

It provides a setter method to override and supply your own algorithm resolver (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L221). 

However, the way jwtAlgorithmResolver is being used to create NimbusJwtDecoder in  buildDecoder() function (here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L140) , it enforces only one algorithm to be supplied to NimbusJwtDecoder which it uses internally during the key selection process. 

This implementation works fine if IDP uses only one algorithm at a time as in that case, we can customize the algorithm to be used by supplying your custom jwtAlgorithmResolver using setJwsAlgorithmResolver() setter method. 

However, if IDP uses more than one algorithms to sign ID Token, there is no way we can supply all the algorithms used by IDP and so the token processing fails during the whole OIDC based authentication process when a token is signed with a different algorithm than what's used to initialize NimbusJwtDecoder through OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory. 

**To Reproduce**
Have IDP use more than one algorithm (say RS256 and ES256 both) to sign JWT and make sure it randomly alternates between these algorithms for oidc based authentication request flow. 

**Expected behavior**
As long as user has authenticated successfully, the client app should be able to process and validate IDTokens regardless of which algorithm was used out of the set of configured algorithms. 

**Sample**

Unfortunately, I can't share any code as it's private to the organization I work for, however, I'll update this ticket if I can somehow create a sample with some public IDP (e.g. google) where I can configure multiple algorithms.

'comments': 6, 'created_at': '2022-03-31T21:38:32Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-01T18:35:02Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory by default defines jwsAlgorithmResolver with RS256 as signature algorithm for Signed JWTs (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L86)

It provides a setter method to override and supply your own algorithm resolver (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L221). 

However, the way jwtAlgorithmResolver is being used to create NimbusJwtDecoder in  buildDecoder() function (here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L140) , it enforces only one algorithm to be supplied to NimbusJwtDecoder which it uses internally during the key selection process. 

This implementation works fine if IDP uses only one algorithm at a time as in that case, we can customize the algorithm to be used by supplying your custom jwtAlgorithmResolver using setJwsAlgorithmResolver() setter method. 

However, if IDP uses more than one algorithms to sign ID Token, there is no way we can supply all the algorithms used by IDP and so the token processing fails during the whole OIDC based authentication process when a token is signed with a different algorithm than what's used to initialize NimbusJwtDecoder through OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory. 

**To Reproduce**
Have IDP use more than one algorithm (say RS256 and ES256 both) to sign JWT and make sure it randomly alternates between these algorithms for oidc based authentication request flow. 

**Expected behavior**
As long as user has authenticated successfully, the client app should be able to process and validate IDTokens regardless of which algorithm was used out of the set of configured algorithms. 

**Sample**

Unfortunately, I can't share any code as it's private to the organization I work for, however, I'll update this ticket if I can somehow create a sample with some public IDP (e.g. google) where I can configure multiple algorithms.

For example, if client-A expects `RS256` and client-B expects `ES256`, then the logic within the custom `jwsAlgorithmResolver` can be implemented this way.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1086207164/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

{'action': 'created', 'issue': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049', 'repository_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security', 'labels_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049/labels{/name}', 'comments_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049/comments', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049/events', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049', 'id': 1188832641, 'node_id': 'I_kwDOADAMs85G3CWB', 'number': 11049, 'title': "OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory allows only one algorithm (default to RS256) to be specified for JWT Decoder. Doesn't work when there are multiple algorithms used by IDP to issue signed JWT Tokens", 'user': {'login': 'jigneshshukla', 'id': 11949776, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjExOTQ5Nzc2', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/11949776?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jigneshshukla', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jigneshshukla/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'labels': [{'id': 84690758, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWw4NDY5MDc1OA==', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/labels/status:%20waiting-for-triage', 'name': 'status: waiting-for-triage', 'color': 'fef2c0', 'default': False, 'description': "An issue we've not yet triaged"}, {'id': 322225079, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWwzMjIyMjUwNzk=', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/labels/type:%20bug', 'name': 'type: bug', 'color': 'e3d9fc', 'default': False, 'description': 'A general bug'}], 'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-03-31T21:38:32Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-01T16:01:22Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory by default defines jwsAlgorithmResolver with RS256 as signature algorithm for Signed JWTs (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L86)

It provides a setter method to override and supply your own algorithm resolver (here at https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L221). 

However, the way jwtAlgorithmResolver is being used to create NimbusJwtDecoder in  buildDecoder() function (here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/1edfa07d27a17ebdd0da88f6ba23ce333cba7a37/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L140) , it enforces only one algorithm to be supplied to NimbusJwtDecoder which it uses internally during the key selection process. 

This implementation works fine if IDP uses only one algorithm at a time as in that case, we can customize the algorithm to be used by supplying your custom jwtAlgorithmResolver using setJwsAlgorithmResolver() setter method. 

However, if IDP uses more than one algorithms to sign ID Token, there is no way we can supply all the algorithms used by IDP and so the token processing fails during the whole OIDC based authentication process when a token is signed with a different algorithm than what's used to initialize NimbusJwtDecoder through OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory. 

**To Reproduce**
Have IDP use more than one algorithm (say RS256 and ES256 both) to sign JWT and make sure it randomly alternates between these algorithms for oidc based authentication request flow. 

**Expected behavior**
As long as user has authenticated successfully, the client app should be able to process and validate IDTokens regardless of which algorithm was used out of the set of configured algorithms. 

**Sample**

Unfortunately, I can't share any code as it's private to the organization I work for, however, I'll update this ticket if I can somehow create a sample with some public IDP (e.g. google) where I can configure multiple algorithms. 
", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1086088295', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049#issuecomment-1086088295', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/11049', 'id': 1086088295, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs85AvGRn', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-04-01T16:01:22Z', 'updated_at': '2022-04-01T16:01:22Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "@jigneshshukla I'm not seeing the issue you are having.

The `Map` of `jwtDecoders` is keyed by `clientRegistration.getRegistrationId()`, which means each `ClientRegistration` has it's own `JwtDecoder` instance.

A custom `jwsAlgorithmResolver` would receive a `ClientRegistration` and it should return the `JwsAlgorithm` that is expected to be used by the provider for the the ID Token signature. The key word to note is **expected**, because when a client is registered with a provider, part of it's registration metadata is [id_token_signed_response_alg](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-registration-1_0.html#ClientMetadata). Therefore, if the custom `jwsAlgorithmResolver` is configured correctly then there shouldn't be any issues with ID Token signature verification.

Can you provide more details or a [minimal sample](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example) or test that reproduces the issue so I can troubleshoot further?", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1086088295/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520.patch', 'merged_at': None}, 'body': 'Add JWT client authentication support for `private_key_jwt` and `client_secret_jwt`.

### Related specifications

**RFC 7521**
[4.2.  Using Assertions for Client Authentication](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7521#section-4.2)

**RFC 7523**
[2.2.  Using JWTs for Client Authentication](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7523#section-2.2)

**OpenID Connect Core 1.0**
[9.  Client Authentication](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#ClientAuthentication)

The best place to start to see how to configure and customize JWT client authentication support are the following tests:

- `DefaultAuthorizationCodeTokenResponseClientTests`:
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationPrivateKeyJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationClientSecretJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`

- `DefaultClientCredentialsTokenResponseClientTests`:
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationPrivateKeyJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`
  - `getTokenResponseWhenAuthenticationClientSecretJwtThenFormParametersAreSent()`

Closes gh-8175', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/9520/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/9520/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1085046555', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/9520#issuecomment-1085046555', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/9520', 'id': 1085046555, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs85ArH8b', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-31T20:03:39Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-31T20:03:39Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': '@sabareeshkkanan 

> do you have an working example by configuring using application.yml

`NimbusJwtClientAuthenticationParametersConverter` cannot be auto-configured using `application.yml`. It needs to be explicitly configured by passing it a `Function<ClientRegistration, JWK> jwkResolver` via constructor. The `jwkResolver` contains the key used to sign the Jwt Client assertion.

Please look at this [test](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/5cf40ab9da5e69fdd82d280a41e4e514a4d52140/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/test/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/endpoint/DefaultAuthorizationCodeTokenResponseClientTests.java#L192) as it demonstrates the explicit code configuration.

**Expected behavior**
The authorizationGrantType REFRESH_TOKEN is explicit configured in the RegisteredClient, so the refreshToken is expected in response.

'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "I am thinking of A single Authorization server in an organization providing identity federation for multiple clients(tenants), where tenant data should be isolated from each other. 

Other OAuth servers like KeyCloak provide Multi-tenancy. https://www.keycloak.org/docs/latest/securing_apps/index.html#_multi_tenancy

One of the following approaches can be configured:

Separate Schema – one schema per tenant in the same physical database instance
Separate Database – one separate physical database instance per tenant
Partitioned (Discriminator) Data – the data for each tenant is partitioned by a discriminator value(ex. A column for tenant identifier)

Organization can choose which of the above approach is suitable for any given tenant. For example 'A' tenants wants it's data completed isolated and is ok with separate physical database. Where 'B' tenant is ok with separate schema in shared physical database etc.

I am not sure if it is in roadmap or as a framework we want to implement this. Can anyone please direct me to resources if you have one that would be awesome.
Thanks

Related https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/499", 'reactions': {'url': '[rfc8414#section-2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8414#section-2) 

>`issuer`  REQUIRED.  The authorization server's issuer identifier, which is a URL that uses the "https" scheme
and has no query or fragment components.

The "https" schema in development may be unsuited, but others should be vailidated. 

- required 
- no query
- no fragment

I'm not sure if the above has been considered, further discussion is required', 'created_at': '2022-03-19T15:08:13Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-29T15:52:54Z', 'closed_at': None, 'merged_at': None, - required 
- no query
- no fragment

> "invalid_client":  Client authentication failed (e.g., unknown
         client, no client authentication included, or unsupported
         authentication method).  The authorization server MAY return an
         HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) status code to indicate which HTTP
         authentication schemes are supported.  If the client attempted
         to authenticate via the "Authorization" request header field,
         the authorization server MUST respond with an HTTP 401
         (Unauthorized) status code and include the "WWW-Authenticate"
         response header field matching the authentication scheme used
         by the client.

We should respond with the required authentication scheme when a client fails authentication.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/468/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 1, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/468/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1081991962', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/468#issuecomment-1081991962', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/468', 'id': 1081991962, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODsirpc5AfeMa', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-29T15:08:41Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-29T15:08:41Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Thanks for your interest @Enkosz. None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Expected Behavior**
Add the possibility to restrict PKCE method to s256 only (e.g. for authorization code grant for public clients)

**Current Behavior**
Currently both PKCE methods (_s256_ and _plain_) are active by default (which is fine), but they cannot be configured.

**Context**
Sometimes (or often?) it is just not required to support the _plain_ method in production. Therefore disabling _plain_ per configuration could force all clients (that may or may not be under your control) to use the _s256_  method (which is a better protection against eavesdroppers, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636 7.2) and thus decrease the attack surface a little bit.
', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1081983538', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571#issuecomment-1081983538', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571', 'id': 1081983538, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODsirpc5AfcIy', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-29T15:02:06Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-29T15:02:06Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Thanks for your interest @gourav !

'2022-03-29T14:28:02Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-29T14:28:02Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Thanks for the PR @akuhtz.

Allowing for this dynamic configuration via property would not work with the proposed change since `messages-client` and `messages-resource` sample are both configured with `issuer-uri: http://localhost:9000`.

Also, there are a few other hardcoded references to the `9000` port that would require updates as well, e.g. README, `custom-consent-authorizationserver` and `federated-identity-authorizationserver`.

The samples are meant to be as simple as possible with the minimum amount of code required to get up and running. Users can take the samples as a starting point and modify as necessary.

We're going to keep the default port as `9000` for all samples in order to keep things simple.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1081942513/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
As an OAuth 2.1 compliant authorization server, Spring Authorization Server does not require PKCE for all authorization code grants. Based on the current authorization code grant implementation here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/blob/main/oauth2-authorization-server/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/server/authorization/web/authentication/OAuth2AuthorizationCodeRequestAuthenticationConverter.java#L137 and  here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/blob/main/oauth2-authorization-server/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/server/authorization/authentication/OAuth2AuthorizationCodeRequestAuthenticationProvider.java#L225, PKCE is only required for public clients. Based on the latest OAuth 2.1 draft (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-1-05), PKCE is required for any client making a basic authorization code grant request.

Specifically, section 10 of the current draft indicates: 
```
*     The authorization code grant is extended with the functionality
      from PKCE ([RFC7636]) such that the default method of using the
      authorization code grant according to this specification requires
      the addition of the PKCE parameters
```

The one exception is specified in section 7.6:
```
   To prevent injection of authorization codes into the client, using
   code_challenge and code_verifier is REQUIRED for clients, and
   authorization servers MUST enforce their use, unless both of the
   following criteria are met:

   *  The client is a confidential client.
   *  In the specific deployment and the specific request, there is
      reasonable assurance by the authorization server that the client
      implements the OpenID Connect nonce mechanism properly.
   
   In this case, using and enforcing code_challenge and code_verifier is
   still RECOMMENDED.
``` 

**To Reproduce**
Attempt to retrieve an OAuth access token using an OAuth 2.0 authorization code grant flow without PKCE from a confidential client and watch it succeed.

**Expected behavior**
Any authorization code grant request submitted without proper PKCE parameters fails, with the possible/optional exception of the scenario described in section 7.6 of the OAuth 2.1 draft. 

**Sample**
The existing project's client/server sample exhibits this behavior.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/652/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/652/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'milestone': None, 'comments': 2, 'created_at': '2022-03-21T23:46:03Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-29T13:56:50Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-29T13:56:49Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
As an OAuth 2.1 compliant authorization server, Spring Authorization Server does not require PKCE for all authorization code grants. Based on the current authorization code grant implementation here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/blob/main/oauth2-authorization-server/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/server/authorization/web/authentication/OAuth2AuthorizationCodeRequestAuthenticationConverter.java#L137 and  here https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/blob/main/oauth2-authorization-server/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/server/authorization/authentication/OAuth2AuthorizationCodeRequestAuthenticationProvider.java#L225, PKCE is only required for public clients. Based on the latest OAuth 2.1 draft (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-1-05), PKCE is required for any client making a basic authorization code grant request.

Specifically, section 10 of the current draft indicates: 
```
*     The authorization code grant is extended with the functionality
      from PKCE ([RFC7636]) such that the default method of using the
      authorization code grant according to this specification requires
      the addition of the PKCE parameters
```

The one exception is specified in section 7.6:
```
   To prevent injection of authorization codes into the client, using
   code_challenge and code_verifier is REQUIRED for clients, and
   authorization servers MUST enforce their use, unless both of the
   following criteria are met:

   *  The client is a confidential client.
   *  In the specific deployment and the specific request, there is
      reasonable assurance by the authorization server that the client
      implements the OpenID Connect nonce mechanism properly.
   
   In this case, using and enforcing code_challenge and code_verifier is
   still RECOMMENDED.
``` 

**To Reproduce**
Attempt to retrieve an OAuth access token using an OAuth 2.0 authorization code grant flow without PKCE from a confidential client and watch it succeed.

**Expected behavior**
Any authorization code grant request submitted without proper PKCE parameters fails, with the possible/optional exception of the scenario described in section 7.6 of the OAuth 2.1 draft. 

**Sample**
The existing project's client/server sample exhibits this behavior.", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/652/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/652/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1081905334', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/652#issuecomment-1081905334', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/652', 'id': 1081905334, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODsirpc5AfJC2', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-29T13:56:49Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-29T13:56:49Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': '@mikesaurus Thanks for the report. The current implementation with **not requiring PKCE for confidential clients** is intentional at this time. OAuth 2.1 is still in draft and likely not all OAuth 2.0 Clients would implement this requirement, which would make those clients unusable with Spring Authorization Server if we were to be strict with requiring PKCE.

> The fix for this might be as easy as defaulting `require_proof_key` to `true` for all clients [here](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/blob/3e6f8ff42a3de08746894944cebd8c6d52c287ef/oauth2-authorization-server/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/server/authorization/config/ClientSettings.java#L88). Then, if you wanted to allow clients to override, they could still set `require_proof_key` to `false`

`ClientSettings.Builder.requireProofKey(false)` is the default to ensure compatibility with OAuth 2.0 "Confidential" Clients that do not implement PKCE. However, you can easily override the default via `ClientSettings.Builder.requireProofKey(true)` if the client is OAuth 2.1 compatible.

I hope this makes sense? I'm going to close this as the current behaviour is expected. If you still feel there is room for improvement, please let us know and we can continue the discussion here or open a separate issue.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1081905334/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Expected Behavior**
Add the possibility to restrict PKCE method to s256 only (e.g. for authorization code grant for public clients)

**Current Behavior**
Currently both PKCE methods (_s256_ and _plain_) are active by default (which is fine), but they cannot be configured.

**Context**
Sometimes (or often?) it is just not required to support the _plain_ method in production. Therefore disabling _plain_ per configuration could force all clients (that may or may not be under your control) to use the _s256_  method (which is a better protection against eavesdroppers, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636 7.2) and thus decrease the attack surface a little bit.
', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1079051985', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571#issuecomment-1079051985', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/571', 'id': 1079051985, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDODsirpc5AUQbR', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-25T13:55:27Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-25T13:55:27Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': '@gourav Just a heads up that our top priority for `0.3.0` is the reference documentation so the team is focusing on that for the next 8 weeks. This means that new features and enhancements will be very light for `0.3.0`.

Having said that, I'm not sure we'll be adding a configuration to disable the `plain` method.

As stated in [7.2 Protection against Eavesdroppers](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636#section-7.2):

> Because of this, "plain" SHOULD NOT be used and exists only for
   compatibility with deployed implementations where the request path is
   already protected.  **The "plain" method SHOULD NOT be used in new
   implementations**, unless they cannot support "S256" for some technical
   reason.

Right now I'm leaning towards removing support for the `plain` method but I'm still thinking it over.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1079051985/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'body': 'Running:
```
 ./gradlew build --warning-mode all
```
shows deprecation warnings which will become fatal errors with Gradle 7.

This PR replaces:
 - `compile` by `implementation`(or `api` when needed),
 - `testCompile` by `testImplementation`, 
 - `testRuntime` by `testRuntimeOnly`.

This solves partly issue https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/572, which is still blocked by https://github.com/spring-gradle-plugins/spring-build-conventions/issues/95.', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/645/reactions', None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Describe the bug**
Project and samples are not buildable in Java 17 due to Gradle 7 requirement and deprecation/removal of `compile` dependency syntax.

**To Reproduce**
Open project in environment running J17, and update `gradle-wrapper.properties` to a J17-supported version, e.g `7.3.2`

**Expected behavior**
The project to be usable in an up-to-date environment.

**Cause**
The `compile` instruction was deprecated in Gradle 6, per https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/upgrading_version_5.html

It was removed from Gradle 7, and 7.3 is required for Java 17.

**Solution**
Change all `compile` instructions in gradle dependancy lists to `implementation` (and all `testCompile` to `testImplementation`). There are a few other changes per the upgrade instructions, but I didn't see instances of them in the checked files. This change will not adverssely impact earlier-version users as it's to bring in line with Gradle 6 deprecation.", 'reactions': {'url': 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hi,

class `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.user.OAuth2UserAuthority` includes its `attributes` for the calculation of `hashCode` and `equals`.
In case of `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.user.OidcUserAuthority extends OAuth2UserAuthority` those attributes come from `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.OidcIdToken` and `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.OidcUserInfo` via `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.user.OidcUserAuthority.collectClaims(OidcIdToken, OidcUserInfo)` function. It seems that due to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/main/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L101 whenever (always?) the claims contain a `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.IdTokenClaimNames.ISS`, it is there as an instance of class `java.net.URL`.

This is a problem, since due to historical reasons, URL performs DNS lookups whenever its equals/hashCode is used. Instances of URL must not be used in any containers requiring use of equals/hashCode.

A simple solution would be to change it to be an instance of `java.net.URI`. Would this break something? I didn't craft a pull request since I have no idea if this kind of change would be a major breaking change for spring-security...?", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1078868822', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673#issuecomment-1078868822', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673', 'id': 1078868822, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs85ATjtW', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-25T10:14:09Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-25T10:14:09Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': '@jyrimatti Take a look at the OpenID Connect Core 1.0 spec, in section [2.  ID Token](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#IDToken):

> iss
       REQUIRED. Issuer Identifier for the Issuer of the response. **The iss value is a case sensitive URL** using the https scheme that contains scheme, host, and optionally, port number and path components and no query or fragment components.

The `iss` is a `URL` so `URL OidcIdToken.getIssuer()` is correct and no changes are required in `OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory` or `ReactiveOidcIdTokenDecoderFactory`.

The only change required is what I proposed in previous [comment](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673#issuecomment-1070668310) - either `URL.toExternalForm()` OR convert to `URI`.

'updated_at': '2022-03-23T10:25:05Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-16T18:35:01Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'The goal of [PKCE](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636) is to provide an added level of security for **OAuth 2.0 public clients** (utilizing the Authorization Code Grant) from an authorization code interception attack.

However, based on OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice, in [section 2.1.1.  Authorization Code Grant](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-11#section-2.1.1):

> Note: although PKCE so far was recommended as a mechanism **to protect
   native apps**, this advice applies to all kinds of OAuth clients,
   **including web applications**.

It can also be leveraged for **confidential clients** for an added layer of security.

Given this, we should consider adding this support. From initial research, Okta does support this scenario where a confidential client is used to authenticate with the Token Endpoint and the `code_verifier` is sent as a parameter.

We should conduct further research to see which other providers support this client configuration/registration.

See this [comment](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/6485#discussion_r258058756) for further details.

Related #6446', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/6548/reactions', 'total_count': 18, '+1': 18, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, > http.getSharedObject(ClientRegistrationRepository.class), // this is null, and not an available bean

`ClientRegistrationRepository` is a required `@Bean` for `oauth2-client` so this would fail at start up. Something is going on with your configuration.

I noticed `http.oauth2ResourceServer(OAuth2ResourceServerConfigurer::jwt)`. Is this needed for your `oauth2-client` application? '2022-03-22T19:21:26Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': '**Describe the bug**
The problem occurs when accessing /.well-known/openid-configuration after logging in

**To Reproduce**
Start https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/tree/main/samples/default-authorizationserver
Access http://auth-server:9000/login to log in
Access the http://auth-server:9000/.well-known/openid-configuration endpoint
The console throws an exception and then returns a 302 redirect

+server:
+  port: 9000
+
+spring:
+  security:
+    oauth2:
+      client:
+        registration:
+          google-idp:
+            provider: google
+            client-id: ${GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID:test}
+            client-secret: ${GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET:secret}
+            scope: openid, https://www.googleapis.com/auth/userinfo.profile, https://www.googleapis.com/auth/userinfo.email
+            client-name: Sign in with Google
+          github-idp:
+            provider: github
+            client-id: ${GITHUB_CLIENT_ID:test}
+            client-secret: ${GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET:secret}', 'path': 'samples/federated-identity-authorizationserver/src/main/resources/application.yml', 'position': 18, 'original_position': 18, '2022-03-17T17:18:00Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-17T14:50:25Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'Currently spring security OAuth 2.0 client use provider details token uri as value for JWT aud claim of the assertion in OAuth 2.0 Client Authentication.

[rfc 7523](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7523#section-3) say :
> The token endpoint URL of the authorization server MAY be used as a value for an "aud" element to identify the authorization server as an intended audience of the JWT.

Rfc say may, not must. I would like to be able to use another value (I have to call a oauth 2 server that require a value different from the token url).

Current spring security behavior is provided by [NimbusJwtClientAuthenticationParametersConverter](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/main/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/endpoint/NimbusJwtClientAuthenticationParametersConverter.java#L134). Overriding it’s behavior requires to copy/paste hundreds of lines as it’s a final class and it use many package-private classes.

'2022-03-17T09:37:14Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2021-12-31T06:35:28Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-17T09:45:36Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "Hi,

class `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.user.OAuth2UserAuthority` includes its `attributes` for the calculation of `hashCode` and `equals`.
In case of `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.user.OidcUserAuthority extends OAuth2UserAuthority` those attributes come from `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.OidcIdToken` and `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.OidcUserInfo` via `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.user.OidcUserAuthority.collectClaims(OidcIdToken, OidcUserInfo)` function. It seems that due to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/main/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/main/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/oidc/authentication/OidcIdTokenDecoderFactory.java#L101 whenever (always?) the claims contain a `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.oidc.IdTokenClaimNames.ISS`, it is there as an instance of class `java.net.URL`.

This is a problem, since due to historical reasons, URL performs DNS lookups whenever its equals/hashCode is used. Instances of URL must not be used in any containers requiring use of equals/hashCode.

A simple solution would be to change it to be an instance of `java.net.URI`. Would this break something? I didn't craft a pull request since I have no idea if this kind of change would be a major breaking change for spring-security...?", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1070668310', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673#issuecomment-1070668310', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10673', 'id': 1070668310, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs84_0RoW', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-17T09:45:36Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-17T09:45:36Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': "Thanks for the report @jyrimatti. This will be a breaking change so I've scheduled it for `6.0.x`.

I think the required change is to ensure the `Map` returned from `OidcUserAuthority.collectClaims()` replaces all `URL` values with `URL.toExternalForm()`.

Would you be interested in submitting a PR for this?", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1070668310/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}

'2022-03-17T09:29:45Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-17T09:27:11Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'draft': False, 'pull_request': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/pulls/10559', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/10559', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/10559.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/10559.patch', 'merged_at': None}, 'body': 'In `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.ClientAuthenticationMethod` the equals method was comparing the value using `equalsIgnoreCase`, however the `hashCode` was returning the original string's `hashCode`. This meant that if the value was only differing in the case, `equals` would return true, but the `hashCode` wouldn't match, causing all sorts of problems, such as in a Collection calling `contains` returning false. E.g.:

```
ClientAuthenticationMethod foo1 = new ClientAuthenticationMethod("foo")
ClientAuthenticationMethod foo2 = new ClientAuthenticationMethod("FOO")

foo1.equals(foo2);    // This returns true

List<ClientAuthenticationMethod> list = new ArrayList<>();
list.add(foo1);

list.contains(foo2);  // This returns false
```

I fixed the issue by calling an explicit toLowerCase() in both cases.

{'action': 'closed', 'number': 10559, 'pull_request': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/pulls/10559', 'id': 790826974, 'node_id': 'PR_kwDOADAMs84vIw_e', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/10559', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/10559.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/10559.patch', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/10559', 'number': 10559, 'state': 'closed', 'locked': False, 'title': 'Fixed ClientAuthenticationMethod inconsistent equals and hashCode', 'user': {'login': 'jlaci', 'id': 2863973, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjI4NjM5NzM=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/2863973?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jlaci', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jlaci/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'body': 'In `org.springframework.security.oauth2.core.ClientAuthenticationMethod` the equals method was comparing the value using `equalsIgnoreCase`, however the `hashCode` was returning the original string's `hashCode`. This meant that if the value was only differing in the case, `equals` would return true, but the `hashCode` wouldn't match, causing all sorts of problems, such as in a Collection calling `contains` returning false. E.g.:

```
ClientAuthenticationMethod foo1 = new ClientAuthenticationMethod("foo")
ClientAuthenticationMethod foo2 = new ClientAuthenticationMethod("FOO")

foo1.equals(foo2);    // This returns true

List<ClientAuthenticationMethod> list = new ArrayList<>();
list.add(foo1);

list.contains(foo2);  // This returns false
```

I fixed the issue by calling an explicit toLowerCase() in both cases.

 ====
+
+=== Customizing the JWT assertion
+
+The JWT produced by `NimbusJwtClientAuthenticationParametersConverter` contains the `iss`, `sub`, `aud`, `jti`, `iat` and `exp` claims by default. You can customize the headers and/or claims by providing a `Customizer<NimbusJwtClientAuthenticationParametersConverter.JwtClientAuthenticationContext<T>>` to `setJwtClientAssertionCustomizer()`. +=== Customizing the JWT assertion
+
+The JWT produced by `NimbusJwtClientAuthenticationParametersConverter` contains the `iss`, `sub`, `aud`, `jti`, `iat` and `exp` claims by default. '2022-03-16T19:07:22Z', 'closed_at': '2022-03-16T18:35:01Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'The goal of [PKCE](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636) is to provide an added level of security for **OAuth 2.0 public clients** (utilizing the Authorization Code Grant) from an authorization code interception attack.

However, based on OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice, in [section 2.1.1.  Authorization Code Grant](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-11#section-2.1.1):

> Note: although PKCE so far was recommended as a mechanism **to protect
   native apps**, this advice applies to all kinds of OAuth clients,
   **including web applications**.

It can also be leveraged for **confidential clients** for an added layer of security.

Given this, we should consider adding this support. From initial research, Okta does support this scenario where a confidential client is used to authenticate with the Token Endpoint and the `code_verifier` is sent as a parameter.

We should conduct further research to see which other providers support this client configuration/registration.

See this [comment](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/pull/6485#discussion_r258058756) for further details.

Related #6446', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/6548/reactions', 'total_count': 18, '+1': 18, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/6548/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/comments/1069506144', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/6548#issuecomment-1069506144', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/6548', 'id': 1069506144, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOADAMs84_v15g', 'user': {'login': 'jgrandja', 'id': 10884212, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEwODg0MjEy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/10884212?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jgrandja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jgrandja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2022-03-16T19:07:22Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-16T19:07:22Z', 'author_association': 'CONTRIBUTOR', 'body': '@bdemers @sdoxsee This feature enhancement is now available.

The OAuth 2.1 Draft, in [Section 9.8 Authorization Codes](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-oauth-v2-1-01#section-9.8), states the following:

> Clients MUST prevent injection (replay) of authorization codes into
   the authorization response by attackers.  To this end, using
   "code_challenge" and "code_verifier" is REQUIRED for clients and
   authorization servers MUST enforce their use, **unless both of the
   following criteria are met**:
> 
>  *  The client is a confidential client.
> 
>  *  In the specific deployment and the specific request, there is
      reasonable assurance for authorization server that the client
      implements the OpenID Connect "nonce" mechanism properly.
>
 >  In this case, using and enforcing "code_challenge" and
   "code_verifier" is still RECOMMENDED.

In a nutshell, confidential clients that perform the OpenID Connect 1.0 `authorization_code` flow and implement the `nonce` parameter are NOT required to implement PKCE, however, it is still RECOMMENDED. For all other cases, PKCE is REQUIRED for confidential clients.

**NOTE:** This feature enhancement is **NOT enabled by default**, and must be explicitly configured. The main reasons why it was implemented this way are:
1. PKCE is NOT required for ALL confidential clients as explained in previous point.
2. OAuth 2.1 is still in draft and not all OAuth 2 providers will enforce PKCE for confidential clients, so we need to ensure we don't break existing client applications with the introduction of this enhancement.

To leverage this enhancement and configure PKCE for confidential clients, please see the following tests for usage:
- Enable PKCE for [ALL confidential clients](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/54b033078b8031e020324c0af6d46e93c4628660/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/test/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/web/DefaultOAuth2AuthorizationRequestResolverTests.java#L409)
- Enable PKCE for [a specific confidential client](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/blob/54b033078b8031e020324c0af6d46e93c4628660/oauth2/oauth2-client/src/test/java/org/springframework/security/oauth2/client/web/DefaultOAuth2AuthorizationRequestResolverTests.java#L429)

Feedback on this enhancement would be greatly appreciated before it's released in `5.7.0`. Thanks!

'labels': [{'id': 1974969182, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWwxOTc0OTY5MTgy', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/labels/type:%20enhancement', 'name': 'type: enhancement', 'color': 'e3d9fc', 'default': False, 'description': 'A general enhancement'}], 'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2022-03-07T21:21:59Z', 'updated_at': '2022-03-11T20:40:35Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': "**Expected Behavior**
It would be great if we could add a custom claim validator for client authentication using JWT assertion. This will allow additional validations to be done on the jwt assertion authentication.

**Current Behavior**
Right now for client authentication using JWT Assertion, DelegatingOAuth2TokenValidator comes with the default validators:  return new DelegatingOAuth2TokenValidator<>(
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.ISS, clientId::equals),
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.SUB, clientId::equals),
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.AUD, containsProviderAudience()),
                    new JwtClaimValidator<>(JwtClaimNames.EXP, Objects::nonNull),
                    new JwtTimestampValidator()

**Context**
In this implementation, the clients will send JWT assertions with custom claims which I am planning to validate before issuing the access token. I haven't found away to configure this.

I can certainly see how people may interpret parts of the spec differently because it is written generically in some sections and is left up to the implementor to choose the appropriate strategy for implementation.

The spec states:

> If the client type is confidential or the client was issued client
   credentials (or assigned other authentication requirements), the
   client MUST authenticate with the authorization server as described
   in [Section 3.2.1](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-3.2.1).

This MAY be interpreted....if the client does not have any credentials assigned then it DOES NOT require authentication on the token endpoint. This most definitely will not be a default configuration that Spring Authorization Server will provide out-of-the-box. I hope the reasons are obvious.

> The authorization server must consider the security implications of
interacting with unauthenticated clients and take measures to limit
the potential exposure of other credentials (e.g., refresh tokens)
issued to such clients.

We have considered the implications of adding support for refresh tokens for public clients alongside refresh token rotation but this scenario will increase the potential attack surface as detailed in this [comment](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/pull/335#issuecomment-1059236894).', 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/spring-projects/spring-authorization-server/issues/comments/1059257851/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}
